contextId.information: The word "you" refers to Jehoshaphat, but refers to both him and his army. Here "Moab" stands for "the army of Moab." AT: "Will you and your army go with me to fight against the army of Moab?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Will you go with me against Moab to battle?

contextId.information: This refers to the kings accompanied by their armies. AT: "the kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom and their armies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom

contextId.information: Here the word "kings" refers to both the kings and their armies. AT: "the kings had come with their armies" or "the kings and their armies had come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the kings had come

contextId.information: The soldiers are referring to themselves here as "Moab." AT: "soldiers of Moab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: So now, Moab

contextId.information: Here "Israel" refers only to the Israelite soldiers and not to the whole nation of Israel. AT: "the area where the Israelite soldiers had set up their tents" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: camp of Israel

contextId.information: The king's "view" refer to what he thinks about something. AT: "in the king's opinion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: in his master's view

contextId.information: Here the "Arameans" refer to the Aramean soldiers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: The Arameans had gone out

contextId.information: The phrase "with your own eyes" emphasizes that the captain will certainly see the things that Elisha prophesied. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:07:01|7:2]]. AT: "you yourself will watch these things happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: you will watch it happen with your own eyes

contextId.information: Hazael was to take many gifts, not just one. AT: "take many gifts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Take a gift

contextId.information: The names of the three kings listed here are synecdoches and refer also to their armies that accompany them. AT: "Ahaziah's army joined the army of King Joram of Israel to fight against the army of King Hazael of Aram" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Ahaziah went with Joram son of Ahab, to fight against Hazael, king of Aram

contextId.information: Here "Hazael" refers to himself and his army. AT: "the army of Hazael king of Aram" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: against Hazael king of Aram

contextId.information: "your master's descendants" Here the man that they selected to be king is referred to as Ahab's royal line of descendants. AT: "to defend your master's descendant" or "to defend him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: for your master's royal line

contextId.information: Here "Hazael" refers to himself and his army. AT: "Hazael and his army" or "King Hazael's Aramean army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Hazael defeated

contextId.information: The phrase "eyes of Yahweh" represents Yahweh's entire being. AT: "what was pleasing to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: what was right in the eyes of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "hands" refers to the men. AT: "to men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: into the hands of men

contextId.information: This refers to Hazael's army as well as to Hazael. AT: "Hazael king of Aram and his army attacked ... Then they turned to attack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Hazael king of Aram attacked ... Hazael then turned to attack

contextId.information: "and the power that his army showed when they fought against the army of Amaziah king of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: and his might by which he fought against Amaziah king of Judah

contextId.information: Here "Jehoash" and "him" refer to their armies. AT: "Jehoash's army attacked Ben Hadad's army three times" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Jehoash attacked him three times

contextId.information: The phrase "Pul the king of Assyria" represents Pul and his army. AT: "Pul the king of Assyria came with his army against the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Pul the king of Assyria came against the land

contextId.information: Here "He" refers to Tiglath Pileser and represents him and his army. Carrying the people to Assyria represents forcing them to go to Assyria. AT: "He and his army forced the people to go to Assyria  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He carried away the people to Assyria

contextId.information: Here "day" is a synecdoche for a period of time. AT: "This is a time of distress" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: This day is a day of distress

contextId.information: "Words" is a synecdoche for the message of the words. AT: "the whole message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: all the words

contextId.information: These boasts made by Sennacherib could only be fulfilled by his army. The pronoun "I" represents by synecdoche all the forces under his control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I have gone up ... I will cut down ... I will enter

contextId.information: "Days" is synecdoche to refer to an undefined span of time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the days

contextId.information: The feet are a synecdoche for the person, and the name of the people group is a synecdoche for the people themselves. AT: "the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the feet of Israel

contextId.information: "let their enemies defeat them and take over their land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: give them into the hand of their enemies

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents the workmen as a whole. AT: "given it to the workmen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: given it into the hand of the workmen

contextId.information: The eyes are synecdoche for the whole person. AT: "they forced king Zedekiah to watch them kill his sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: they slaughtered them before his eyes
